title: Function-Based Video Self-Modeling to Modify Disruptive Behavior
description: For students who have had minimal success on current behavior plans, the study will explore the effects of using a functional analysis procedure called the Interview Informed Synthesized Contingency Analysis (IISCA; Hanley, et al., 2014) to inform a video self-modeling treatment.  We believe this combination will provide reliable information about the individual's behavior and offer the learner a visual portrayal of an appropriate communicative response amidst a condition that typically triggers aggressive and disruptive behavior.
researcher_description: PI: Kate M. Sadler; University of Virginia;
participant_description: Students who have had minimal success on current behavior plans

title: Feasibility of Using the IISCA Across Various Environments to Analyze and Treat Disruptive Behavior
description: Using interview-informed synthesized contingency analysis (IISCA) to control ASD behavior during assessment period for creating a safe environment for practitioners and patients.
researcher_description: PI: Kate M. Sadler; University of Virginia; Additional Investigators: Einar Ingvarsson (Virginia Institute of Autism), Kristie Jones (University of Virginia), Sarah Emily Schutz (University of Virginia)

title: Establishing a Water-Safety Program for Children with ASD
description: This study will extend Tucker and Ingvarsson (2017). YMCA swim instructor will be trained to teach VIA students water safety using a behavioral skills training protocol developed by Tucker & Ingvarsson (2017).
researcher_description: PI: Rose Nevill; University of Virginia; Additional Investigators: Einar Ingvarsson (Virginia Institute of Autism), Micah Mazurek (University of Virginia), Marylise Tucker (Empower Behavioral Health, TX), Emily Meltzer (University of Virginia) Lauren Haskins (Virginia Institute of Autism), Kate Sadler (University of Virginia);
participant_description: Participants will be selected to participate based upon the following criteria: (1) currently receiving educational or therapy services at the Virginia Institute of Autism; having a clinical diagnosis of ASD, (2) being able to tolerate the integration of swim sessions into their school-day routine without marked emotional dysregulation, (3) reports from a teacher, clinician, and/or parent indicating that he or she is able to follow simple 1-2 step commands and is able to imitate motor movements, and (4) reports from teacher, clinician, and/or parent that he or she presents with minimally challenging behaviors.
outcomes: Benefits of study participation to the participants and parents/caregivers include: participants’ acquisition of potentially life-saving water safety and swim skills. Through this initial pilot program, VIA and the YMCA hope to create a sustainable water safety skills program for individuals with ASD that will remain in place after the data collection period has ended.
